onboarding.title: Branding
onboarding.description: Build your artist identity from the ground up.

articles.title: Branding
articles.description: Your brand is your reputation‚Äîhow people talk about you when you're not there.

content.text: Your brand is your reputation. It's how people talk about you when you're not there. What are the first three things that come to mind when someone hears your name?
What is a Brand?
For artists, your brand is personal‚Äîyou ARE the brand. It's not just a logo or color palette. It's the complete experience people have when they interact with you.
Brand Recognition in Action
When you mention Deadmau5, people immediately think of the iconic mouse head. When someone talks about Daft Punk, they picture the robot helmets. That instant recognition is the power of branding.
Why Being Different Works
People have an instinctive need to belong. When you dare to be different, you become attractive to people who want to be part of something unique. Your brand becomes the tribe they want to join.

content.title: Exercise
content.text: Ask three friends: 'What are the first three things you think of when you hear my name?' Write down their answers‚Äîthese should align with your brand values.

articles.title: Core Values
articles.description: Discover what makes you stand out from the crowd.

content.text: Your core values are the foundation of your brand. They're what you represent as an artist and what makes you different from everyone else.
Discovering Your Uniqueness
Start by observing yourself honestly. What makes you different? What do you care deeply about?

content.title: Questions to Ask Yourself
items: What do you do daily that's different from others?
Do you have strong opinions you're not afraid to share?
Is your way of speaking or dressing unique?

content.text: Ask people around you for their perspective‚Äîthey often see things about you that you don't notice yourself.
Building Your Brand House

Once you've identified at least three core values, think of them as pillars that support your entire brand. Every decision you make‚Äîfrom visuals to music to how you interact with fans‚Äîshould reflect these values.

articles.title: Visualization
articles.description: Define your goals and create a clear vision for your career.

content.text: Before you can achieve your goals, you need to see them clearly. Visualization is a powerful tool used by successful artists and athletes alike.
Why Visualization Works
When you visualize your success in detail, your brain starts to recognize opportunities that align with that vision. It's not magic‚Äîit's focus.
How to Visualize Your Career

items: Close your eyes and imagine yourself 5 years from now
What does your audience look like?

content.title: Exercise
content.text: Write a detailed description of your ideal day as a successful artist. Where do you wake up? What do you do? Who do you work with?

articles.title: Artist Name
articles.description: Choose a name that represents your brand and is memorable.

content.text: Your artist name is often the first thing people encounter. It should be memorable, represent your brand, and work across all platforms.
What Makes a Good Artist Name?

items: Available as a domain and social handles
Sounds good when announced on stage

content.text: Before committing to a name, search it thoroughly. Check social media, streaming platforms, and trademark databases. You don't want legal issues later.

Don't overthink it. Consider that "Apple" probably seemed like an odd choice for a tech company before it became one of the world's most valuable brands. What matters most is that you commit to your name and build your reputation around it. Pick something that feels right, then focus on making great music‚Äîthat's what will make your name memorable.
Testing Your Name
Say your potential name out loud. Imagine a festival announcer saying 'Please welcome to the stage...' followed by your name. Does it work?

articles.title: Logo
articles.description: Create a visual symbol that makes you instantly recognizable.

content.text: Your logo is a visual shorthand for your brand. It should be simple enough to recognize at a glance, but distinctive enough to be memorable.
Logo Principles

items: Keep it simple‚Äîcomplex logos don't scale well
Make it work in black and white
Ensure it's readable at small sizes
Consider how it looks on merchandise

content.text: Your logo doesn't need to explain what you do. Nike's swoosh doesn't show shoes. Apple's logo isn't a computer. Focus on being memorable.
Where to Use Your Logo
Once you have a logo, use it consistently: social media profiles, music artwork, website, merchandise, press materials, and stage visuals.

articles.title: Moodboard
articles.description: Develop your visual direction and aesthetic.

content.text: A moodboard is a visual collection that defines the look and feel of your brand. It guides all your visual decisions and keeps everything consistent.
What to Include

items: Reference images from artists you admire

content.text: How to Create One
Use Pinterest, a physical board, or design software. Collect 15-30 images that feel like 'you'. Look for common themes‚Äîthose are your visual brand elements.
Share your moodboard with designers, photographers, and anyone creating visuals for you. It ensures everyone is aligned on your aesthetic.

articles.title: Press Photos
articles.description: Get professional photos that work across all platforms.

content.text: Professional press photos are essential. They're used by promoters, media, and platforms. Bad photos can lose you opportunities before anyone hears your music.
What You Need

items: A few vertical options for Stories/Reels
Both color and black & white versions

content.text: Working with Photographers
Share your moodboard with your photographer before the shoot. Discuss locations, wardrobe, and the mood you want to capture.
Update your press photos regularly. Using the same photos for years makes you look inactive. Aim for new photos at least once a year.

articles.title: Biography
articles.description: Write a compelling story that connects with your audience.

content.text: Your biography tells your story. It's used by promoters, journalists, and fans to understand who you are. A good bio creates connection and intrigue.
Three Versions You Need

items: Short (50 words): For social media profiles
Medium (150 words): For event listings and quick references
Long (300+ words): For press kits and detailed features

content.text: What to Include
Start with a hook that grabs attention. Include your genre, notable achievements, unique story elements, and what makes you different. End with what you're working on now.
Avoid clich√©s like 'passionate about music since childhood' or 'genre-defying sound.' Be specific and authentic.

articles.title: Stage Performance
articles.description: Develop your presence and create memorable experiences.

content.text: Your stage performance is where your brand comes alive. It's not just about the music‚Äîit's the complete experience you create for your audience.
Elements of Stage Presence
Practice and Preparation
Great performers make it look effortless, but that comes from practice. Record yourself performing. Watch it back. Identify what works and what doesn't.
Study artists you admire. What do they do between songs? How do they use the stage? What makes their performance memorable?

articles.title: Tone of Voice
articles.description: Define how you communicate with your audience.

content.text: Your tone of voice is how you 'speak' as a brand‚Äîin captions, interviews, and all communications. It should be consistent and authentic to you.
Defining Your Voice
Are you playful or serious? Mysterious or open? Professional or casual? Your tone should match your brand personality and resonate with your audience.
Consistency is Key
Once you define your voice, use it everywhere: social media, email newsletters, interviews, and website copy. Inconsistency confuses your audience.

articles.title: Your Sound
articles.description: Identify and develop your unique sonic signature.

content.text: Your sound is what makes people recognize your music within seconds. It's a combination of production choices, musical preferences, and creative instincts that are uniquely yours.
Finding Your Sound
Your sound often emerges naturally from the intersection of your influences, your skills, and your personality. Don't force it‚Äîlet it develop.
Listen to your last 10 tracks. What elements appear consistently? Those patterns are your emerging sound.

articles.title: Online Presence
articles.description: Build and optimize your digital footprint.

content.text: Your online presence is often someone's first encounter with you. Every platform should reflect your brand consistently and make it easy for people to find and follow you.
Essential Platforms
Profile Consistency
Use the same profile photo, username, and bio format across platforms. Make it easy for fans to find and recognize you everywhere.
Claim your username on all platforms, even ones you don't use yet. This prevents others from taking it.

articles.title: Press Kit (EPK)
articles.description: Create a professional kit that opens doors.

content.text: An Electronic Press Kit (EPK) is your professional portfolio. It contains everything bookers, journalists, and labels need to know about you in one place.
What to Include
Format Options
Create both a downloadable PDF version and a page on your website. The website version can include embedded music and videos.
Keep your EPK updated. Outdated statistics or old press photos make you look inactive.

management.title: Management
management.description: Understand the artist lifecycle and build your network.

articles.title: Artist DNA
articles.description: Understand what makes you unique as an artist.

content.text: Your Artist DNA is the combination of traits, influences, and characteristics that make you uniquely you. Understanding it helps you make authentic decisions about your career.
Components of Artist DNA

items: Your values and what you stand for

content.text: Why It Matters
When you understand your DNA, decisions become easier. Should you take this collaboration? Does this venue fit your brand? Your DNA guides these choices.

content.title: Exercise
content.text: Write down 5 artists who influenced you, 5 personal traits that define you, and 5 goals you want to achieve. The patterns that emerge are your DNA.

articles.title: The Artist Cycle
articles.description: Navigate the different phases of an artist's career.

content.text: Every artist career moves through predictable phases. Understanding where you are helps you focus on the right activities for your current stage.
The Phases

items: Discovery: Building your sound and identity
Development: Growing your audience and skills
Establishment: Consistent releases and regular gigs

content.text: Phase-Appropriate Activities
Don't try to do everything at once. In the Discovery phase, focus on your music and brand. In Development, focus on building audience. Match your efforts to your phase.
Be honest about where you are. Trying to act like an established artist when you're still developing can actually slow your progress.

articles.title: The Fan Journey
articles.description: Map how fans discover and engage with you.

content.text: Fans don't become superfans overnight. They go through a journey from discovering you to becoming loyal supporters. Understanding this journey helps you nurture relationships.
The Journey Stages

items: Awareness: They hear about you for the first time
Interest: They check out your music
Engagement: They follow you on social media
Conversion: They buy tickets, merch, or subscribe
Loyalty: They actively promote you to others

content.text: Moving Fans Through Stages
Each stage requires different actions. Awareness needs visibility. Interest needs great music. Engagement needs consistent content. Conversion needs calls to action. Loyalty needs community.

content.title: Exercise
content.text: Think about your favorite artist. How did you discover them? What made you become a dedicated fan? Apply those insights to your own strategy.

articles.title: Building Your Network
articles.description: Connect with the right people in the industry.

content.text: The music industry runs on relationships. Your network can open doors that talent alone cannot. But networking isn't about collecting contacts‚Äîit's about building genuine relationships.
Who to Connect With
How to Network Effectively

items: Be genuine‚Äîpeople spot fake interest instantly
Give before you ask‚Äîoffer value first
Follow up‚Äîa connection without follow-through is worthless
Stay in touch‚Äîregular, meaningful contact builds relationships

content.text: Keep a simple spreadsheet of your contacts: name, role, how you met, last contact, and any notes. Review it monthly.

marketing.title: Marketing
marketing.description: Promote your music and grow your audience.

articles.title: What is Marketing?
articles.description: Understand the fundamentals of promoting your music.

content.text: Marketing is how you get your music heard. It's not about being 'salesy'‚Äîit's about connecting your art with the people who will love it.
Marketing Basics for Artists
At its core, marketing answers: Who is your audience? Where are they? What do they care about? How can you reach them?
The Marketing Mix

items: Product: Your music, brand, and experience
Place: Where people find you (platforms, venues)
Promotion: How you spread the word

content.text: Great marketing feels natural when it comes from genuine enthusiasm for your music and real care for your audience.

articles.title: Newsworthiness
articles.description: Learn what makes content worth sharing.

content.text: Not everything you do is newsworthy, and that's okay. Understanding what makes something worth covering helps you create moments that get attention.
What Makes Something Newsworthy?

items: Relevance: It relates to current trends

content.text: Creating Newsworthy Moments
Plan your releases and announcements around moments that maximize impact. A new track is news. A new track that samples a classic hit is bigger news.

articles.title: Reaching Out
articles.description: Master the art of professional outreach.

content.text: Cold outreach is part of the game. Whether you're contacting blogs, playlist curators, or promoters, how you reach out matters as much as what you're offering.
Outreach Principles

items: Keep it short‚Äîbusy people skim emails
Be specific‚Äîwhat exactly are you asking for?
Make it easy‚Äîinclude all needed links

content.text: Never send mass generic emails. Personalized outreach has dramatically higher success rates.

articles.title: Writing a Press Release
articles.description: Craft releases that get media attention.

content.text: A press release announces your news in a format journalists can easily use. Done well, it makes their job easier and increases your chances of coverage.
Press Release Structure

items: Lead paragraph: Who, what, when, where, why
Contact info: How to reach you

content.text: Write your headline and lead paragraph first. If those don't grab attention, the rest doesn't matter.

articles.title: Writing a Newsletter
articles.description: Build direct relationships with your fans.

content.text: Email newsletters let you communicate directly with fans‚Äîno algorithm deciding who sees your content. It's one of your most valuable marketing tools.
Newsletter Best Practices

items: Be consistent‚Äîset a schedule and stick to it
Provide value‚Äîdon't just ask for things
Be personal‚Äîwrite like you're emailing a friend
Include a clear call to action
Keep it scannable‚Äîuse headers and short paragraphs

content.text: Building Your List
Offer something valuable in exchange for email signups: exclusive content, early access, or behind-the-scenes material.

articles.title: Storytelling
articles.description: Create deeper connections through narrative.

content.text: Great brands tell great stories. Your narrative is what makes people remember you and feel connected to your journey.
Brand Storytelling Examples
The world's biggest brands sell stories, not products:

content.caption: Nike's 'Just Do It' sells determination, not shoes

content.text: Your Story as an Artist

items: Your origin: How did you get into music?
Your struggles: What obstacles have you overcome?
Your vision: Where are you heading?
Your values: What do you stand for?

articles.title: Creating Content
articles.description: Develop content that engages your audience.

content.text: Content keeps you connected with your audience between releases. The good news: you don't need expensive equipment‚Äîyour smartphone is enough.
Content Ideas

items.title: Day in the Life
items.text: What does your day look like?

content.text: Real Artist Examples
Top artists share authentic moments that feel genuine and personal:

content.caption: Marshmello sharing a moment backstage after a show

content.text: Consistency beats perfection. Better to post regularly with good content than to wait for the perfect shot.

articles.title: Control Your Content
articles.description: Manage your content strategy effectively.

content.text: Creating content is one thing‚Äîmanaging it effectively is another. A content calendar and clear strategy prevents burnout and ensures consistency.
Content Calendar Basics
Batch Creation
Create content in batches rather than day-by-day. Spend one afternoon creating a week's worth of content. This saves time and ensures consistency.

bookings.title: Bookings
bookings.description: Get gigs at clubs and festivals.

articles.title: What Type of DJ Are You?
articles.description: Identify your style and find your niche.

content.text: Before you can get booked, you need to understand what kind of DJ you are. This determines which venues you target and how you position yourself.
DJ Categories

items: Resident DJ: Regular at one venue, building local following
Touring DJ: Travels for bookings, broader reach
Producer/DJ: Creates own music, plays own productions
Open format: Plays across genres for varied crowds
Specialist: Deep expertise in specific genre

content.text: Finding Your Niche
The riches are in the niches. Being known as the best at something specific is more valuable than being average at everything.

articles.title: Find Your Stage
articles.description: Discover venues that match your style.

content.text: Not every venue is right for every artist. Finding venues that match your sound and style increases your chances of success and leads to better performances.
Researching Venues

items: What genres do they typically book?
What size audiences do they draw?
What's their reputation in the scene?

content.text: Visit venues as a guest first. Understand the vibe, the crowd, and the sound before approaching for bookings.

articles.title: Getting Booked at a Club
articles.description: Strategies for landing club bookings.

content.text: Club bookings are often the foundation of a DJ career. Here's how to approach clubs professionally and increase your chances of getting booked.
The Approach

items: Build a relationship first‚Äîbecome a regular
Network with current residents and staff
Have your EPK ready before approaching
Start with off-peak slots if offered
Prove yourself before asking for more

content.text: What Bookers Look For
Bookers want artists who draw crowds, are professional to work with, and fit the venue's brand. Demonstrate all three.

articles.title: Getting Booked at a Festival
articles.description: Stand out to festival programmers.

content.text: Festival bookings are highly competitive. Programmers receive hundreds of submissions, so standing out requires strategy and patience.
Festival Booking Realities

items: Lineup is often decided by relationships and buzz
Smaller stages are your way in
Regional festivals are more accessible than flagship events

content.text: Building Festival-Ready Profile
Festivals want artists with momentum. Focus on building buzz through releases, smaller gigs, and social proof before targeting major festivals.

articles.title: How To Write A Booker
articles.description: Craft emails that get responses.

content.text: Your booking inquiry email is often your first impression. A well-crafted email can open doors; a sloppy one gets deleted.
Email Structure

items: Greeting: Use their name if you know it
Close: Thank them, provide contact info

content.text: Keep it under 200 words. Bookers are busy‚Äîif they want more info, they'll click your links.

articles.title: Build Your Riders
articles.description: Create professional technical and hospitality riders.

content.text: Riders communicate your requirements to venues. A professional rider ensures you have what you need to perform well.
Technical Rider

items: Equipment you need (CDJs, mixer model, etc.)

content.text: Hospitality Rider
Keep requirements reasonable for your level. Demanding too much as an emerging artist can hurt your reputation.

articles.title: Create a Setlist
articles.description: Build sets that take audiences on a journey.

content.text: A great set tells a story. It has structure, flow, and memorable moments. Planning your set‚Äîwhile staying flexible‚Äîleads to better performances.
Set Structure

items: Opening: Set the mood, read the room

content.text: Preparation Tips
Prepare more music than you need. Know your tracks well enough to adapt to the crowd's energy.

articles.title: Track Booking Information
articles.description: Stay organized and professional.

content.text: As bookings increase, organization becomes essential. Tracking details properly prevents mistakes and maintains your professional reputation.
What to Track
Use a simple spreadsheet or booking app. Always confirm details in writing‚Äîverbal agreements get forgotten.

articles.title: Preparing Your Performance
articles.description: Get ready for showtime.

content.text: Preparation separates professionals from amateurs. What you do before the gig affects how you perform during it.
Before the Gig

items: Confirm all details with the venue
Plan your journey with buffer time

content.text: Day of the Gig

items: Meet the sound engineer and venue staff
Test your equipment in the booth
Relax and focus before going on

articles.title: Making a Lasting Impression
articles.description: Leave every gig with new opportunities.

content.text: How you handle yourself before, during, and after a gig determines whether you get booked again‚Äîand recommended to others.
During the Gig

items: Read and respond to the crowd
Deliver the best performance you can

content.text: After the Gig

items: Thank the promoter and venue staff
Stay in touch for future opportunities

content.text: The music industry is small. Everyone talks. Your reputation travels faster than your music.

articles.title: Flows of Income
articles.description: Understand all your potential revenue streams.

content.text: Modern artists have more ways to earn money than ever before. Understanding your revenue streams helps you build a sustainable career.
Revenue Streams
Diversification
Don't rely on a single income source. The most resilient careers have multiple revenue streams that complement each other.

articles.title: Invoicing
articles.description: Create professional invoices and get paid.

content.text: Professional invoicing ensures you get paid on time and maintains your business reputation. Treat it seriously from day one.
Invoice Essentials

items: Your business name and contact info

content.text: Best Practices

items: Follow up politely if payment is late

articles.title: Calculate Your Profit & Loss
articles.description: Track your financial performance.

content.text: Understanding your profit and loss tells you whether you're building a sustainable career or just moving money around.
The Formula
Profit = Revenue - Expenses. Simple in theory, but you need to track everything to know your real numbers.
Common Expenses
Keep all receipts. You'll need them for taxes and accurate tracking.

articles.title: Budgeting
articles.description: Plan your spending for sustainable growth.

content.text: A budget is your financial roadmap. Without one, you're navigating your career blindly.
Why Budget?
Budget Categories
Divide your income: essentials (rent, bills), career investment (equipment, marketing), savings, and personal spending.
Review your budget monthly. Your financial situation changes, and your budget should adapt with it.

articles.title: Royalties
articles.description: Understand how music royalties work.

content.text: Royalties are payments you receive when your music is used. Understanding the different types ensures you collect everything you're owed.
Types of Royalties

items: Master: From use of your recordings

content.text: Collecting Your Royalties

items: Register with a PRO (ASCAP, BMI, PRS, etc.)

content.text: Many artists leave money on the table by not registering their works properly. Set this up correctly from the start.

articles.title: Signing a Record Deal
articles.description: Navigate record deal negotiations.

content.text: A record deal can accelerate your career‚Äîor trap you in a bad contract for years. Understanding what you're signing is crucial.
Types of Deals

items: Traditional: Label funds everything, owns masters
Licensing: You license for a period, retain ownership
360 Deal: Label takes percentage of all income

content.text: Key Terms to Understand
ALWAYS have a lawyer review any contract before signing. The cost is nothing compared to a bad deal.

articles.title: Signing a Management Agreement
articles.description: Evaluate contracts and protect yourself.

content.text: A manager can be incredibly valuable, but the wrong deal can cost you dearly. Understand what you're agreeing to.
What Managers Do
Contract Considerations
Meet multiple managers before deciding. The relationship matters as much as the terms.

articles.title: Basic Music Rights
articles.description: Understand copyright and publishing.

content.text: Understanding music rights protects your work and ensures you get paid. There are two main copyrights in every recording.
The Two Copyrights

items: Master: The specific recording of that song

content.text: Who Owns What
As an independent artist, you likely own both. When you sign deals, you may transfer or license some rights. Know what you're giving up.
Protecting Your Rights

items: Copyright exists automatically when you create
